content:
Adding more complexity to the engine compartment and interior can really make your Ferrari model stand out. Wiring, hoses, and engine components like cylinders or pistons can add a lot of visual interest and realism to the model. And detailing the interior with textured seats and a more detailed dashboard can make the model feel more immersive and authentic.

That paint chipping technique sounds like a great way to add some realism to your model. Masking tape can be a really useful tool for creating sharp, defined edges and lines, and using it to create a chipped, worn look can add a lot of character to the model. I'm sure it'll be a great addition to your Ferrari.

It's great that you've been working on your model sporadically over the past three weeks. Consistency is key when it comes to making progress on a project, and it's awesome that you've been able to dedicate some time to it each week. Five hours on a Sunday afternoon is a great chunk of time to get started on a project, and it's impressive that you've been able to make progress on it since then.

How many hours do you think you've put into the model so far? And do you have a rough estimate of how many hours you think it'll take to complete the project?

Also, have you thought about displaying your model once it's complete? Do you have a display case or shelf in mind, or are you planning to enter it into any model shows or competitions?
